snippet: As widely expected, shareholders at Chesapeake Energy voted to withhold support for two board members in an open revolt that is likely to remake the board of directors and further dilute the power of Aubrey K. McClendon, the besieged chief executive,...
abstract: As widely expected, shareholders at Chesapeake Energy voted to withhold support for two board members in an open revolt that is likely to remake the board of directors and further dilute the power of Aubrey K. McClendon, the besieged chief executive, Clifford Krauss writes in The New York Times. A few hours before the shareholder meeting, Chesapeake announced that it was selling pipelines to raise $4 billion.
